38390947.review:
The game doesn't seem to know it's audience as the difficulty of the steps cap out at around a measly DDR 13 or ITG 8. Charts are well written and work great with an index playstyle so it's a shame that the difficulty level never went up to anything interesting.

The battle system is difficult to learn as it's hard to keep up with what is going on and what affects what all while following the steps. Later it gets pretty easy to cheese the bosses and it becomes a slog of playing through the same sounding chiptune inspired synth-pop over and over for a majority of the game. Instead of saying there is variety in the music, I'll say there are some exceptions but just too few and few inbetween for it to be significant.

The way the game is presented, they did a great job, it looks great. Props to the artists. The interface doesn't support the mouse for reasons unknown. Either that or it's because I have an X360 controller plugged into my PC. The game used button prompts labelled with X360 buttons even though I'm using the keyboard.

There's no way to set it to upscroll, more of a nitpick but it would be really nice to have the option instead of being forced to read downscroll.

I can't say anything on the story or the voice acting because I literally skipped all that. Big thanks for making it skippable, I really appreciate that instead of forcing me to watch all the cutscenes.

I'd strongly just recommend StepMania over this. (Why not both?) Well there are plenty of more interesting gimmiky stuff made for StepMania rather than this 1 trick pony of this game.

37805958.review:
Um dos melhores jogos musicais disponíveis pra PC, na minha opinião.

Com uma boa variedade de gêneros musicais e uma mecânica bem interessante (imagine Rock Band Unplugged com elementos de RPG) que faz você não poder contar apenas com suas habilidades em jogos musicais ou em RPGs, mas sim tentar balancear as duas coisas ao mesmo tempo. É um desafio divertido e nenhum dos lados dessa moeda é terrívelmente complexo, realmente não é tão difícil quanto soa a princípio.

Comparando com o jogo mais próximo que consigo lembrar em questão de gêneros (Crypt Of The Necrodancer), eu acho que nessa mistura de jogo musical com RPGs, Metronomicon tende a ser mais parecido com jogos musicais clássicos  como DanceDanceRevolution ou Guitar Hero enquanto Necrodancer tende mais para o lado RPG do espectro dessa mistura de gêneros. Então se você está mais habituado com jogos musicais do que RPGs e quer experimentar a mistura dos dois gêneros, minha recomendação é começar com Metronomicon.

36805362.review:
[i]The Metronomicon[/i], пожалуй, одна из тех игр, которая отложиться в моей памяти надолго. А главное, ведь в игре нет ни реалистичной 3D-графики, нет сюжета, который дает задуматься перед тем, как окончательно уснуть в теплой постельке, а также, наверно надоевших всем, лутбоксах. И это хорошо.

[h1]С танцами и бубном[/h1]

Игру можно порекомендовать тем, у кого нет много времени на изучение сложных механик или долгой прокачки героя и лута  тысяч монстров. Не стоит бояться RPG, считая, что все с этим связанное - бесконечный гринд фармом и выполнением кучи дополнительных квестов. Здесь все намного проще: выполнил одну песенку (по продолжительности нету и больше 4 минут), получил опыт для героев и, если повезло (а везет часто), несколько предметов для героев. После чего героев одеваем и идем по песенкам дальше к боссам, а затем по новым локациям.

[h1]We got the moves![/h1]

Если Вы играли в любую игру, связанную с ритмикой и музыкой, то геймплей понять не составит труда. Есть четыре дорожки, по которым бегут нотки, Вам лишь остается их вовремя собирать, тыкая по кнопочкам вовремя и переключаясь между героями, чтобы использовать тот или иной спелл. Разнообразия героев и способностей хватает: на момент выпуска обзора в игре имеется 9 героев, каждый обладает 8 способностями. Запутаться в них достаточно сложно, что-то лечит, что-то калечит, что-то накладывает баффы. Комбинаций из различных героев и связей их способностей очень много, не говоря уже о том, сколько всевозможной экипировки можно получить.

[h1]Dance, fools![/h1]

Помимо прохождения сюжетной линии, можно сыграть на арене, поставить рекорды в DLC-миссиях, а также спуститься туда, куда ступает лишь нога отважного авантюриста-танцора: в Бесконечный режим.

[u]Сюжет[/u]
Не замысловат и прост. Вычисляется по формуле: герои + проблемы = решенные проблемы. По мере прохождения Вас будут знакомить с различными аспектами игры, в виде дополнительных героев, арены, битовых способностей и т.д.

[u]Арена[/u]
Прошли уровень в режиме сюжета? А сможете ли Вы его пройти в более усложненной форме? Что, значит зачем? Ради великого лута, разумеется.

[u]Бесконечный режим[/u]
Продержитесь как можно дольше! Каждая песня усложняет игру случайным модификатором, из-за чего игра может превратиться в "Спасти рядового игрока %username%". При прохождении, выдаются особые боевые очки, тратить их можно как на различные дополнительные модификаторы, так и на особые пассивные навыки героев.

[h1]Танго для двоих[/h1]

У Вас есть лучший друг, который часто заходит к Вам в гости? Усаживайте его рядом с собой и проходите игру в локальной кооперативе (к сожалению, пока не смог заценить этот режим). Внимание: играть одновременно с одного устройства ввода нельзя.

[h1]Великий танцор диско[/h1]

Считаете, что игра казуальная и таким заядлым хардкорщикам нет в ней места? Как бы не так. Каждая песня имеет 3 уровня сложности, прохождение на Hard некоторых может стать настоящим испытанием. А уж если Вы хотите попасть в таблицы рекордов... Ну, здесь придется ужасно попотеть.

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Заключительная оценка:[/th]
        [th]9/10[/th]
    [/tr]
[table]

Игра подойдет практически каждому: огромный набор музыки, различные цели в игре, а также неплохой мультяшный стиль делают свое дело и даже уже пройдя игру давным-давно, хочется ещё раз зайти и прогнать "Fighting with Melody".  Разработчик достаточно активен на форуме и, если у Вас возникли какие-то трудности, постарается помочь (тут лучше только со знанием английского).

36633256.review:
No jokes. Serious review. Deadpan serious.

This is literally DDR with an RPG laid overtop of it. Down to the song menu and difficulties. If DDR doesn't appeal, tread carefully and watch your time played in case you want a refund. I only have a bit clocked as of this review but I can tell you it's DDR with an RPG.

If you're into rhythm games like DDR, FFR, and Stepmania then you'll find yourself at home rather quickly as the game gently insists there's totally room for an RPG in Stepmania. (And there is, apparently.) Like DDR, you get to select a song which you preview in the menu (it even looks like DDR's menu). Once you choose a song, that begins the battle.

Once in battle, you switch between one of four characters' step charts, and follow the arrows like in DDR; you can stop after activating an attack at a first, second, or third power level. Switching is smooth, and the game will only start tracking your steps once you start input on one character. It's highly designed for fluidity. Thankfully, the step charts are most of what you have to pay attention to.

But legitimately, DDR with an RPG inside of it.

To think I grew up beliving Mario Paint was the wildest combination of games-- a coloring book, a music maker and a minigame all in one...

...now look where we ended up.

36384988.review:
Rythm game meets RPG light. There's a ton of great songs in here and the gameplay is addictive enough to carry you through the game easily. Once you've beaten the campaign, there's still more DLC tracks, challenges and all that kinda stuff for you.

Basic gameplay is a "dance-off". Your group of 4 vs. the enemies. You can outfit your troupe with different skills and items. After that it's simply "hit the correct colored input buttons on your controller" (or other input device). If you can match and mix your attack types you can also do bonus damage vs. certain elements, e.g. lightning vs. water.

The game is a decent challenge for people who are not used to button combinations, even on easy, because you WILL need both hands (I used the left stick on A,B on the xbox controller to get through the game). You will quite regularly have to combine two different inputs: left/down or up/right or left/right, up/down. I guess, it's possible with a keyboard, maybe even a programmed mouse if that even works or a different input device. I'd have liked to actually try out a real dance mat, but oh well. No place, no time, no money. If you turn the difficulty to medium or hard, be prepared to just feel inadequate. At least there will never be more than 2 button prompts at once, but the general speed those prompts need pressing increases to kinda double the easy mode rate. 

It's a good game, got a decent play time, and it's cheap. Only caveat is that you kinda have to like rythm games and dance music (mostly electro, but there's 1 or 2 rock songs and some jazz-y titles).

36273628.review:
『音楽と一体化することで不思議な力が現れる世界でモンスターの動きが活性化！原因を突き止めろ！』

音ゲーとRPGを組み合わせたクールでノリノリな作品。
使うボタンはシフトと矢印だけなので操作自体はとても簡単。悪く言えば単調ですが、複雑な音ゲーなんてやってらんないしね。
上から落ちてくる矢印を音に合わせて押していき、自分でカスタマイズ化した技を繰り出して敵にダメージを与えていく。
K〇NAMIのダンレボとスク〇ニのシアトリズムをくっつけて戦闘システムを強化したような感じです。


始めるといきなり４人分のノーツが降ってくるので慌てますが、戦士っぽい人のを優先して押すようにするとサクサク進めるかと。左のゲージがやばくなったらなんかイラッと来るメガネ君を使って回復を。

レベルが上がってくると一人で最大三つの技を装備できます。ノーツを成功させる連続数によって任意で発動できますが、上位にメインの攻撃技をもっていくと難度が高い譜面で泣きをみたりすることも。
また各技、各敵には属性があり、弱点をついていくことでより高いスコアが狙えたり敵からの攻撃頻度を下げられたり。
仲間も増えてきますが、自分は一度しっくり来てしまうとそこからは変えられませんでした。サラちゃんバイオレットちゃんﾌﾞﾋﾌﾞﾋ。それでもクリア可。

慣れてからも色々試行錯誤させてくれるところ、レベル上げれば難度を下げなくてもなんとかなる所はRPGとして好印象です。


全５面構成で曲は５０曲以上とかなり豪勢。なんだかふた昔くらい前のような印象のものが多くて懐かしい気持ちになれます。２面のimagoと１面のkeep movingがお気に入り。


プレイ中は譜面追うのに必死で、コミカルに動く敵味方のアニメーションを全く楽しめないのが難点。まぁビーマニの真ん中だと思えばいいか。良いか？


ギャラリーで曲やイベントを買ったり、各曲のスコアボードで上位を目指したり、決められた課題をこなしてアイテムを獲得したりと、やり混み要素も豊富です。

肩の力を抜いて初めたのにいつの間にか根を詰めてる…そんな感じのゲームです。
ストーリーのクリアだけなら５時間くらいで終わるかと思うんで、積みゲー倉庫で眠らせずに済むんじゃないかと。

35931030.review:
Перетанцуй врага!

В те дни, когда мультиплеер важнее всего, а лутбоксы захватывают одиночные игры, вы можете сами или с другом за одним компом покорить танцпол при помощи.. Фаерболов и силы земли. Заинтриговало? Тогда вы попали куда надо!

Про картинку.
Нарисовано хорошо. Приятная мелочь- персонажи и враги танцуют в ритм песни. Работает на любом ведре. Серьёзно.

Геймплей
Дорожки с нотами (такие, как в guitar hero) четыре. Вам нужно выбирать, какое заклинание вы хотите использовать, и какие четыре героя сформируют вашу команду. Это все-таки ритм-рпг. Нужно попасть в ноты несколько раз подряд, чтобы кастануть заклинание. По началу сложновато собирать длинные цепочки. Сложность в целом растет плавно и игра не бесит.
Ваше умение концентрироваться упростит игру.
Контента много, если вы пройдете первый мир. Там с разнообразием чутка похуже.
Кооп не пробовал, но он только локальный. Мне такой нравится больше онлайнового. Так веселее.

О музыке.
Очень разнообразный саундтрек. Пара треков пошло в мой плейлист, что даже удивительно.
Специальный гость- соллист mindless self indulgence. Его трек тут очень крутой.

Про сюжет
Ничего необычного, но как бэкгроунд- норм.

из минусов- бессмысленность дополнений. Они хоть и дают три трека и испытания, для прохождения они не обязательны. Врядли вы про них даже вспомните.

Итог.
Добротная игра. То, что я ценю в инди- новые идеи и необычный геймплей. 
Очень приятно поиграть вечерком.

35905190.review:
I want to live in this universe.  I love everything about this game.  I want to impress gay raving squirrels while striking flawless disco moves to summon lightning bolts to smite the most stylish and colorful succubi.

Really though, the mood and atmosphere click so hard with me it's unreal.  Everything involved - creatures, locations, fashion, combat maneuvers, attitudes, dance-combat, juxtaposition of the mundane and the exotic - is so wild and outlandish and curiously it all works together in a strangely grounded sense.  The soundtrack is GLORIOUS, the creatures interesting and bizarre, the party and combat mechanics are fun, the reviews are gushing, and the colors blind me to whatever nitpicks I'll find later.

Of course, I know that this sorta style is not for everyone, but I'm glad the game is ultra-proud of what it is.  It was made with pure, niche love and that much is obvious.  I've had this game on my radar since release and I'm kinda sorry I never played it sooner.

35592232.review: Remember that old Acclaim game - Dance!? Well this is that and more on steroids. Play it on hard. Play it with the same split keys (A as left, S as down,  Up and Right arrows). Make left shift move left and (0 insert) on the keypad move right.  Then as you slay a song with a streak from hell you will feel the adrenaline rush - time will dilate, your eyes will see the arrows falling at a noticeably slower speed and your fingers will feel as if they are reading the notes subconsciously even in the most insane sequences. You will find this game accelerates real life time while in game yet after leaving the day can 'drag on' because your brain is in overdrive. It takes skill, timing, a bit of finess and if you want to make it to the top of the leaderboards some supreme skills. Nice game,  hats off to the devs for bringing one of my favorite genres back from the dead :)

Pretty fun if you like rythem music type games plus an rpg party system you have to deal with and select what abilities to use on the enemies.

You can also equip your party with differint stuff to help you win the battles which is cool.

It's like DDR and Beatmania but instead of sticking to one line you need to switch to another of your choice quickly to help your party beat the foe or heal them up.

Pretty cool honestly but if you hate music type games which are becoming more rare for some reason sadly then stay far away if not I think you'll enjoy this.

35284032.review:
There are sevearal significant problems with this game that really killed any enjoyment for me.

1- No Story

2- The Dance Animations aren't very good or varied. Its essentially seems like the same pose repeated, which is pretty bad considering the relative simplicity of the characters, and the fact that you spend most of the game watching the same ones.

3- There doesn't seem to be much to decide or impact in terms of strategy in this game. There IS management in the fight and knowing what things to do, but there's very little you can impact in terms of chosing who you want to add. I was kind of hoping for shops, new classes and the like, but they don't appear anywhere I've seen. 

Functionally, the whole game feels like a very basic rythym game with a bunch of stats tossed on as a gatekeeper to content. 

Personally, I'd rather play a rythym game where the game feels more impactful and the animations are more vaired, like One Finger Death Punch.
35284032.developer_response:
Hiya!

I've ever actually replied to a review before, but it felt appropriate here.
I see you've spent under an hour on the game thus far. That's all good. I'm sorry you didn't enjoy the opening.

Just to add some facts:
There are more characters and classes, yep. :)
There are shops and gear (dear god, tons), yep. :)
There is story (albeit simple), yep. :)

It seems as if you haven't beaten the first zone if you haven't unlocked any additional heroes yet. Along with beating that very first zone, you'd also progress the story through cutscenes, as well as unlock more shops, sidequests, and the arena. I think it's pretty common for most games to start with less heroes/etc in the very first zone of the game.

Sorry you didn't like your first taste in the starter zone, but I hope you enjoy more, once leaving it and reaching all you're requesting.

<3 Danny

35265909.review:
Hermosa mezcla entre RPG y ritmo.
 Los combates son en acorde a la musica. El orden de las magias, ataques y demas, altera su funcion en cuanto al orden en que se va tocando el ritmo. Por ejemplo: Un personaje tiene un ataque basico como primera habilidad y la segunda, una que inspira. Por lo tanto, cuando elijes este personaje y vas acertando al ritmo para ejecutar estas habilidades, notaras que sera en vano que tanto acertarle a los botones solo para dar a una habilidad no tan util como lo es ¨inspirar¨ y que tu ataque no es tan fuerte. Asi que decides, invertir el orden, prefieres poner la habilidad de inspirar como primer beat y el ataque basico, como el ultimo. Pero te llevas una sorpresa.... El ataque basico, al ponerlo como ultimo ritmo, sera mucho mas potente que otras habilidades. Por lo tanto. la ultima habilidad de acorde al ritmo, es mas potente que la anterior.
 La dificultad, para mi, ha sido y sera muy desafiante, en muchos de los casos, injusta. Ya que, estar pendiente de cambiar de personaje para ejecutar un ataque, curacion, defensa y aura, mientras sigues el ritmo de la musica, se siente como si jugaras al guitar hero en 4 consolas diferentes
 Lo malo de este juego, son los dlc´s, que en si, no aportan nada nuevo, solo musica nueva para combatir, pero nada de personajes nuevos, ni items, ni historia adicional. Solo eso.....Musica adicional. 

7/10

35265079.review:
[h1]音ゲー+RPG[/h1]
音楽に合わせてキーを入力し、攻撃や魔法を発動して戦っていく。
入力音がない分、純粋に音楽を楽しみながらプレイ出来ます。
楽曲はどれもイカした音楽ばかりで、お気に入りの曲は本当にノリノリで戦えます。

4人それぞれ3種類のスキル+自動発動スキルを使うのですが、T1、T2、T3と段々強化され、
勿論T3になればかなり強力なスキルを発動出来ます。
そのスキルは自分で自由に決められる為、かなり戦略性が高いです。
T1に回復を置けば、素早く回復出来るけど小回復、
T3なら発動に時間は掛かるけど大回復
みたいな感じです。

よくある属性の4すくみもあり、その属性にどう対処するかも重要なので、
鉄板のスキル構成がなく、完全にプレイヤーに委ねられています。

音ゲーとして遊ぶのはオススメ出来ませんが、
異色のRPGと前もって判った上で遊ぶならかなり面白くオススメ出来るゲームです。

Can I just start by saying I really wanted to DISLIKE this game.  I am a pretentious DDR player who played for 4 years and beat almost all content DDR, ITG, and Stepmania had to offer.  So this game strolls along and is all like "look at me, I'm a dancy game" and I thought it was just stupid, I mean look at that guy with the afro, is he a wizard, is he a disco dancer? wtf is this game?!

Everything just made sense, the step charts were smooth, the rpg element was smart, the team building was in depth, it just felt right. I've kept in communication with the devs for awhile now (I stalk them on twitter) and they are seriously the most legit game devs out there, I mean their next tournament is called W.E.I.N.E.R and let's face it, any game devs that put weiner in their game deserves you to buy their game.

33951362.review:
A delightful combination between two worlds, The Metronomicon takes the rhythm-RPG genre to a whole new platform. On top of its extensive song list, the game features various playable characters that you can fully customise to suit your playstyle. 

You play The Metronomicon just like any rhythm game, but for each series of successful notes hit, you get to activate a character ability in combat. Depending on the character, they will either deal damage, heal, buff your party or place debuffs on the enemy. Personally I don't find all the soundtracks appealing (except a few catchy ones), but I really enjoyed experimenting with the combat abilities and finding the right party composition. Give this game a go if you enjoy the fusion of both rhythm and RPG genres!

32894250.review:
I've been waiting for a game like this since I played the RPG bejeweled spinoffs from popcap.

Having played a lot of rhythm games including all the Konami's DDR and the Benami's Pump it UP! I develop a taste for games where music is the primary focus of the gameplay, that is, learning to react the the notes in a base level that alows you to tackle any song at some degree, and learning the songs' tricky parts. This game provides all of that since it doesnt randomize the notes like others do.

The other aspect of this game is the RPG mechanics, they're very well implemented IMO, very similar to the Bejeweled RPGs where you equip skills that can serve you during the gameplay by giving you a way to executing them during the round, in this case, becoming a section of the song that you have to execute without mistakes to trugger the skill. These skills also have a cooldown during which youll be switching to your other characters to use their skills, they whole thing has great pacing and you never feel taken out of the song's rhythm.

My only problem is that I wish the arrows were actual arrows (with a tail) as opposed to triangles since sometimes, my brain will get confused and start looking at all the notes as the same triangle.

Recommended.

Before I start I'm going to say that I have played very little of this game but boy did it leave an impression on me.
I looked into this shortly after quitting Crypt of the NecroDancer (I am terrible at roguelikes) and thought it looked pretty good, but I wasn't too sure about it. So I waited until a sale to get it.

First off, this game has a really great soundtrack (not like I'd expect any less from a rhythm game). It has nice visuals and an interesting premise as well as a unique execution. However, to me at least, it feels less like a rhythm RPG and more like a rhythm game with added RPG elements; enemies don't have HP so attacking them does nothing more than rack up points, fights end when the song ends, you even traverse the regions by selecting songs.

TLDR it's good but has a way bigger emphasis on the rhythm aspect than the RPG aspect.

i just want to preface this review by saying that at the time of writing this, i have played very little of the main game. what made me want to buy this game more than anything however is the amazing developer of the game that i had met at momocon 2017 and the demo that he had set up there that i just couldn't help but return to every chance that i got.

as he had explained to me, this game is a rhythm-based rpg with all of your typical rpg tropes (leveling, gear, skills, etc.) but it is all controlled by the power of dance. in a very ddr/stepmania fashion, you hit falling arrows in time with the music in order to cast abilities and while an ability is being perfomed, they will have a recovery period so you need to keep switching between the heroes in your party to make the most use of the time you have in the song.

the game has a sense of style that shows the care that went into the game and stays consistantly bright and high energy as you progress. the track list is just as high energy and even features work from jimmy of mindless self indulgence (seriously, look up "fighting with the melody", it's fantastic).

the demo was a blast to play and i can't wait to dump multiple hours into the full game.

29030499.review:
[h1]The Metronomicon[/h1]

Собираем команду из войнов-танцоров и вперед мочить всякую нечисть. Весь бой жмем нужные стрелочки и используем необходимые умения, чтобы убить врага, а затем еще одного и еще одного. Завершаем бой, собираем лут, одеваем его и вперед дальше. И все это под неплохую музыку. 

Во время игры вам доступно 4 героя, у каждого по 3 умения. После прохождения локации можем открывать новых героев со своими умениями. Имеются монстры 5 типов: огонь, вода, земля, молния и ближний бой. Против каждого из этих монстров необходимо использовать правильные умения, чтобы быстрей его убивать. К примеру умения воды против огненного монстра, а не наоборот.

По началу может показаться скучновато и сложно. Но потом втягиваешься. Всю песню приходится постоянно переключаться между 4 героями, нажимать правильные стрелки, смотреть на стихию врага, чтобы использовать умения, а еще успевать смотреть на свои жизни и лечиться. Некоторые бои получаются достаточно бодрые и как я уже сказал, все это под неплохую музыку.

Помимо простого прохождения зоны, где нужно просто продержаться до конца песни в игре присутствуют различные испытания - например нажать 150 раз на стрелки без промахов, убить за 1 песню 8 врагов, нанести определенное количество урона, исцелиться на ххх ед., завалить босса за определенное время.

Также имеются арены, которые похожи также на испытания, со своими наградами.

В итоге про игру можно сказать что получается некая смесь Guitar Hero и игр в которых можно собирать лут, одевать героев в этот лут и кастовать различные умения.

28779463.review:
I was hoping for this to be like Before the Echo, which is an RPG with a rhythm battle system. Unfortunately, it feels more like plain ol' DDR.

There doesn't seem to be any strategy to it as long as you keep hitting notes. I haven't figured out how to tell how much life the party has or what status effects they're under, but as long as I keep rotating through characters, things work out.

I'd probably like it better if the UI were clearer, but as is, there's a better RPG/rhythm hybrid out there and this just makes me want to play that. :( I'll give this another go in the near future (maybe it gets better later), but for now, I just find it disappointing.

Interesting idea and striking visuals, if only I felt like I could focus on them for more than half a second at a time while actually playing the game. The focus required on hitting the notes prevents you from watching any other part of the screen except for quick glances at health bars, and makes it difficult to keep track of what enemies are actually doing.

The experience is not helped by the game's menus being difficult to navigate and the game doing a poor job of explaining the mechanics beyond the basic controls of how to play (at least as far as I bothered playing it I was taken from the tutorial to a list of songs to play, with no indication of the rewards for killing monsters, what the post-song icons meant, or what the elemental shards I seemed to be collecting were to be used for).

28730555.review: This game is a fantastic rhythm game, pitting you in a heroic dance off against various (adorable) enemies. The scenes are beautifully designed & very well animated as are the dance moves of the player/NPC characters. The combat/healing system is very well designed, requiring you to manage four characters by switching between them in order to manage your team health and special attacks. While the game mechanics will require you get used to it, the combat system is intuitive and easy to adapt to.

28359477.review:
[h1]WHY DO I RECOMMEND IT?[/h1]
I recommend it to those who enjoy [i]rhythm games[/i]:
[list]
    [*] Amazing music;
    [*] Fun and challenging concept, yet accessible to players of all skill levels;
	[*] Beautiful and colorful presentation;
    [*] Beat sequences feel natural and make sense in all difficulty levels;
	[*] Game does not punish you (give lesser rewards/block certain content, etc) for playing on easier difficulties;
	[*] Eight interchangeable playable characters and tons of accessories allows for deep customization of gameplay experience;
	[*] Story mode is fun and characters are simple, but charismatic;
	[*] Solid base soundtrack with over 50 songs, plus DLC is just as good;
	[*] You can play with your keyboard, gamepad, dance mat and even guitar contollers from games such as Guitar Hero and Rock Band;
	[*] You can import songs from Stepmania and make your own custom tracks as well with the built-in editor;
	[*] Lots of challenges and replay value.
[/list]

[h1]IF I DID NOT, WHY WOULD I NOT RECOMMEND IT?[/h1]
I would not recommend it based on [i]skill[/i]:
[list]
    [*] It can be somewhat frustrating to grasp its mechanics in the beginning for those who have never/barely played a rhythm game since it throws you right into the fray with no practice mode — gotta learn by failing songs;
    [*] If you're looking for mainstream songs, you're not going to find it here — you can make your own tracks, however, so you can add your own music to the game;
	[*] It is a single player experience — even though there are 4 lanes, a single player controls all 4 of them at the same time;
	[*] Not a biggie, and related to the first bullet point, but there's no "relax/practice mode" in which you can just play for fun and not worry about mistakes.
[/list]

[h1]SHOULD YOU/OTHER PEOPLE BUY IT?[/h1]
It depends on your answer to the [i]following questions[/i]:
[list]
    [*] Do you like DDR (Dance Dance Revolution) / Stepmania?
    [*] Do you like rhythm games in general?
    [*] Do you like Rock Band/Guitar Hero?
    [*] Do you like RPGs?
	[*] Are you looking for an original, fun concept?
	[*] Single player experiences mean more to you than multiplayer/co-op ones?
[/list]

If you answered [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/416790][b]YES[/b][/url] to [url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/416790][b]2 or more questions[/b][/url] above, I'd strongly recommend it to you. It is one of those rare, precious concepts that only come around every once in a long while, and, for the price, you get a big bang for your buck.

The Metronomicon is a mix of DDR (Dance Dance Revolution) and other rhythm games such as Rock Band/Guitar Hero. The DDR aspect is that you have four arrows coming down a lane and you must hit them mostly according to the beat of the song (as opposed to mimicking instruments in games like Guitar Hero) as they pass through a threshold at the bottom of the lane. The Rock Band analogy comes in the form of four different lanes that sort of mix beats and certain instruments, with certain lanes being more difficult/having more notes than others.

You have three attacks/spells that you can trigger by hitting those beats in streaks. A certain number of beats will trigger an attack, and longer streaks allow  you to trigger those different, higher level attacks.

The innovation and challenge comes in the form of four lanes that you must manage at the same time, according to your needs. It is certainly a lot of information to handle in the beginning, and I gotta say that the difficulty is pretty high for beginners. The game expects you to have at least some familiarity with rhythm games, which is both a blessing and a curse.

For instance, none of my friends wanted to even give it a try because they thought it was just too much for them to handle. It can be intimidating. Keeping the beat and hitting notes in sequence is hard enough by itself on a single lane, let alone four of them, while you also have to keep track of your health, the enemy's, status effects, strategy, vulnerabilities, openings and special attacks. 

For beginners, maybe there should be a mode with only a single lane in a tutorial mode of sorts. Or at least a practice room. The tutorial that is in the game now teaches the basics competently, but you already start with four characters and for those who still need to get used to rhythm games it is a hurdle they are mostly often not willing to overcome.

On the other hand, this game has lots of charm. I was pleasantly surprised. What attracted me the most was the premise of controlling several characters in a RPG-like environment through the mechanics of a rhythm game. I must confess the trailer on the store page is very confusing and frustrating, as I was hoping for at least a demonstration of the mechanics, but they make it funny and flashy at the expense of actually presenting the game in a clear and concise way for newcomers. I appreciate the flashy presentation, but a second video showcasing gameplay would be very welcome; I tend not to buy games without having a clear understanding of their core mechanics beforehand, and I suspect some other people might be as bewildered as me the first time I came across this game.

That aside, the amount of polish and love this game has is amazing. The developers are truly passionate about it, and you can see that love clearly even on their store page, with beautiful graphics and colorful descriptions. It is one of the best looking store pages I have come across on Steam in many years. The same care and polish is in the game itself, with its environments, enemies, menus... everything is very bright, colorful and so beautiful and fun to look at. Animations are hit and miss, but given this is an indie developer, you gotta hand it to them for adding so much detail in what must've been quite a tight budget.

Another plus is that the game is very generous with new players. Want to play on easy? No problem! You get the same rewards as anyone else. Difficulty changes only the amount of beats/notes you get per segment, and that only affects your score, for leaderboards purposes.

I myself am not very skilled. I am very uncoordinated, but I love rhythm games. I find it appealing that you get the same rewards no matter the difficulty you play in. That is a great way to balance the game for many different skill levels. I love playing the songs on easy and just relax after a long day at work. If I'm feeling adventurous, I play one or two of my favorite songs on hard, and after a couple of songs I feel very accomplished and entertained.

I used to be a big fan of DDR back in the day. Unfortunately I developed a serious knee injury and had to stop playing on a dance mat, but I kept playing on the controller on my old PSX. This game is an improvement on all aspects of what made rhythm games fun for me. The soundtrack is very diverse and excellent, and I gotta say I appreciate the lack of mainstream artists... it makes it feel unique, all the while presenting excellent artists that for sure deserve a lot more attention; an amazing showcase, for sure.

What worries me is that a lot of people are requesting co-op/multiplayer, and it would be quite sad to see the game change focus from a single-player experience to a mutliplayer one. I wouldn't mind a multiplayer mode, but I feel that fundamental changes would have to be made to the game for that to happen, and that could change the core experience of the game.

Anyway, those are my two cents.

[url=http://store.steampowered.com/app/416790][b]As always, the final choice is up to you.[/b][/url]
[h1][i]Go there, save the day![/i][/h1]

27526208.review:
As a big fan of Stepmania, rhythm games, and rpgs, this game is perfect.  So far i've heard 14 of the 38 songs and have done most of them on easy and medium difficulty, with a couple on hard.

I was initially worried that having 4 scrolling bars along with health bars, abilities, and enemies to keep track of was going to be a bit too much, but i was gladly wrong.  The use of colors and highlighting is subtle, but really helps bring everything together and makes it easy to get all the information you need at a quick glance.

There is a quick and easy tutorial which does a good job introducing all of the mechanics.  It was short, informative, and didn't overstay its welcome.

The soundtrack so far has been amazing, great songs that work well for all difficulties.  Sometimes in DDR/Stepmania songs can seem harder on lower difficulties because its difficult to simplify the beat, but i have yet to experience that.

There's also a lot of replay value. The arena is updated after beating each zone which offers preset challenges to face.  There is also a lot of customizing you can do with party selection, equipment, ability order, team attack, and passive selection that lets you change the play style so the experience is different.  While some items are stat sticks, there are some available that can drastically change how you play.

They also recently added the ability to create your own tracks as well as support for stepmania file types so tons of replay value there.

Though not something I personally care about, they do keep track of your best score for each song/challenge, as well as show you leaderboards for the community which could be a plus for some people.

Support is ongoing, they have released a couple song packs which add some songs and a special item to get for each song at very reasonable prices.  I expect i'll be picking these up during the next holiday sale after i've beaten all the default songs and challenges.

Controls are easily customizable which was good because i wasn't a fan of the default layout they had set up.  They mentioned controller support but I have yet to try since i'm happy with the arrow keys.

I think the only negative i can think of is the lack of mouse support for the menus, but it is functional with the arrow keys as if i was using a controller.


Overall, i highly recommend this game if you are a fan of rhythm games and/or stepmania.  I can already tell this is going to be a game i keep coming back to after i finish all the story missions and challenges.

Update: New update added endless mode and multiplayer support.  Endless mode is interesting, it adds randomized songs with modifiers being added to make it more difficult, but also increase the points you receive.  You can then spend thess points on new unlocks.  Great free update.

26072011.review:
Absolutely phenomenal Rhythm RPG game. After having played through all of Before the Echo I was hoping to see more of that particular style of game, and sure enough Kasedo Games managed to deliver! The Metronomicon has a ridiculous amount of polish to it, with outstanding character models, fluent animation, an easy to learn gameplay, and of course fantastic music. With well over 40 different tracks to dance to you will not be bored of this game for a long time, and if you're one who is already familiar with the concept of dance arrow games like DDR or Stepmania this should be insanely easy to pick up. Additionally there's no need to worry about benched party members being underleveled, so no matter where you are in the game you can always change up your team with no hassle.

The only thing I really don't like about the game are the arena challenges. While the specific challenges are really creative and enjoyable I do not like that a majority of them force you to use a fixed team, and because of that certain challenges are specifically designed in a way to be down to the wire so if you mess up once you fail. While it's still a fun mode, it would be a lot more enjoyable if you could pick your team for all of the challenges, to add that bit of flexibility and creativity when approaching each challenge.

Overall though The Metronomicon proves to be an unbelievable gaming experience, and is a welcome addition to any rhythm game fan especially. Everything was programmed with the utmost care, and aside from one certain achievement, just about everything provides a fair, but challenging difficulty scale. It's also really disappointing that this game isn't getting enough attention because the polish and the time that went into this game is beyond a professional level.

If you've ever been curious about this game then you should definitely get it, you will not be disappointed.

26005872.review:
If you're buying this as a rhythm game like I did, it has basically everything you'd want. The tracks are overwhelmingly worthwhile and fun to play, the difficulty levels are well balanced, and it even has leaderboards for every song and challenge. The only complaint I have as the rhythm game goes is that I had random occasional stutters that usually cost me my combo. That's not a huge deal in this game, but it's extremly annoying. 

If you're buying it primarily as an RPG, don't. The RPG battle mechanics are here to spice up the tired "falling gems" rhythm game, and while they certainly succeed in that sense, they're meant to play second fiddle. As such, you don't need to think about them much at all, and they're not going to make the game worthwhile for you if the rhythm gameplay isn't enough on its own. The story is passably entertaining, but maybe a thousand words at most and not something you're going to remember. None of this is enough of a flaw to be remotely concerning if you're here for the rhythm game. 

The "side quests" offered just a few regular songs with the leaderboard set to track something other than score, like max combo or damage healed. They're not very entertaining, but the ~two dozen arena battles go a step further in also modifying environment and other mechanics, which is fun. 

On a last note, while the acting in the voice acting is well done, several characters clearly weren't recorded in a professional studio and their voices are distractingly low quality. Again, more of an annoyance than a real complaint.

25933383.review:
I really love this game.  I could go on and on about it but among the best things to say:

Great music: A ton of great tracks, all of which I had never been exposed to before.  Some of the tracks are specifically made for this game and I like nearly all of them.  I didn't buy the accompanying soundtrack at first, but now I'm considering it.

Fantastic difficulty curve: This one is important, I was kind of worried when I first tried some hard songs that I would never get good enough to beat them.  A couple weeks in, and I can beat every song on hard and am working my way up on some leaderboards.  It really is addicting because I never felt "stuck" in the game where I stopped accomplishing things.

Cool RPG elements:  At the end of the game, you have enough equipment and unique abilities to really create some special task forces for accomplishing certain goals (like most damage on a song, most enemies killed on a song, most spells cast).  Creating a party around specific goals is actually really fun too, it's not just all about the rhythm game!

Overall for a summary of the game, I would definitely say this is a rhythm game first and an RPG second.  But it's a really well done fusion of the two. 일단 결론적으론 추천인데, 할 말이 좀 많음.

리뷰란게(기술 분석을 제외하고는) 어쨌거나 주관적이 되지 않을 수가 없지만, 이 리뷰는 개인적인 취향이 좀 많이 들어갔으니 참고하기 바람.


일단 이 게임은 
'리듬 게임 + RPG'임.

게임 플레이에 대해서는 말로 설명하는 것 보다 영상 하나 보는 것이 백배 나으므로 생략. 



자, 일단 단점부터...

[list]

  [*]리트라이 메뉴가 없어서 스코어 어택 때 매번 나갔다 다시 로딩하고 시작해야 됨
[/list]
  
  

보기에 따라 장점도 단점도 될 수 있는 것...

이제는 장점...

개인적으로 정말 재미있게 하고 있지만, 할 때 마다 저 단점들이 걸리는데, 솔직히 이번작에서 어떻게 될 것 같지는 않고, 만약 후속작을 낸다면 거기서나 기대해 볼 수 있지 않을까 생각...

25908790.review:
A much, much worse version of Before the Echo. The soundtrack is more diverse, but that's probably the only advantage of Metronomicon (personally, I liked BtE soundtrack a lot more, but everyone has different tastes I guess).

1) The gameplay is a lot less skill-based and a lot more random. If your enemy wants to do damage when you don't have enough HP, it will do damage. If it wants to stun you, it will (and this will affect your final score). There is nothing you can do to control the situation (except for boss attacks, that actually give you a way to prevent the damage, like you normally can in BtE), so you kind of have to guess if you should heal one more time or try to kill one more enemy to get one more kill for the challenge.

2) Interface tries to annoy you any time it has an opportunity to do so. You just finished one enemy and want to see the element of the next one? Well, here is an enemy, but it will take a few moments for its health bar to appear, so unless you want to memorize all the ugly sprites and their corresponding elements, you have to guess blindly. Any reasons to not show you an important UI element? Nope, just game being annoying. Another example: game convinced you that Water skills are blue, Fire ones are red, and Thunder ones are yellow? Basic color coding, works for every skill. Nice. Ok, quick quiz: as your cast spells, your battlefield changes from blue into red into yellow. Does it mean that it changed from water into fire into thunder? Of course not, it means "first, second, third skill slot", duh. It would probably kill the devs to be consistent, or to use different colors for unrelated things.

3) Progression system is so broken that it makes the scoreboard system completely pointless. Want to compete with your friend and compare scores? The same song on the same character level may become a lot easier or harder based on the order in which you first completed these songs in the campaign (and this is permanent), so if you picked some other order, you may never be able to beat someone else's record, no matter how hard you try (the difference in mob levels will stay forever, even when you'll reach the level cap). Why they decided to implement this system is beyond me. And BTW, devs don't care about their game anymore, and have no intention to fix that.

4) Performance. It's hard to believe, but a game that looks like a simple 2D arcade manages to drop frames at random moments on a powerful modern PC. Oh, and 1-2 seconds-long hickups every time you fiddle with the menus will make you hate the UI even outside of the combat.

If you are looking for a fun rhythm game, try Before the Echo instead.

25872020.review:
A daring and exciting combination of Rhythm Game and RPG, The Metronomicon is a unique game that combines elements of Turn-Based RPG Combat (like Final Fantasy) with rhythm-based execution (similar to Guitar Hero). This creates a very interesting blend: taking the familiar concepts behind RPGs such as customizing gear, attacks, utilizing elemental affinities, and changing party setups while adding a fun and challenging layer of execution by using Guitar-Hero like tracks on each hero to perform their different abilities. The players actively swaps between all party members and chooses which to control and what they are casting, which makes the RPG combat elements all in the players hands as well.

I highly recommend this for fans of Rhythm Games & RPG games. Towards the end of the game the songs get quite challenging in execution and the blend of RPG and Rhythm elements create a really unique and enjoyable experience.

25863815.review:
[h1]Are you looking for a Rhythm game with more depth, one that isn't just committing the tracks to muscle memory? Are you an RPG fan looking for something completely different? Do you wish to do battle with a Giant Tentacle Monster with glow-in-the-dark body paint?[/h1]

If so, look no further than The Metronomicon.

Developed by Puuba and published by Kasedo Games, The Metronomicon is a Rhythm/RPG game. Simply put: it's what would happen if you took away the menus of Final Fantasy, and replaced them with four music tracks in the style of Guitar Hero, Dance Dance Revolution, or Rock Band.

The resulting game is near-perfect blend of the two genres, with players having to think, strategize, and time their skills correctly to destroy their enemies, buff their allies, and keep the team alive, while also giving an immediate (and if I may say so myself VERY fun) challenge with trying to hit a long enough series of notes to actually cast those spells and abilities.

This, accompanied by the incredible soundtrack,* a great amount of choice and depth with the player characters, and the many interesting and unique difficulty modifiers make for a great game with a lot of content and tons of replayability—whether you're an expert gunning for the top spots on the leaderboard, or a newbie who keeps dying but keeps coming back for the music and the fun.

[h1]The Good[/h1]

[b]Blended To Perfection[/b] – Match your attack's element to your enemy, get massive damage. Achieve a high streak in the double digits, watch your teammates perform new attacks and abilities that help lay the smack down on your enemies. Do both, and decimate your foes.

Neither the RPG or Rhythm Game elements are overwhelming the other, or just feels like a gimmick—both systems are woven together, and quite well.

[b]Accessible[/b] - Not so great at rhythm games, but a master at RPG mechanics of abusing enemy weaknesses, healing, and buffing? You're good, the game provides items that give flat stat bonuses and a leveling system to gradually overpower the enemies and destroy them through superior stats. Great at rhythm games, a master of high streaks, not so much the synergies of abilities? You're also good, the game also provides items that provide boosts for the streakers among you. Suck at both? Don't worry, the penalties for missing notes and breaking streaks is very forgiving, and the Easy mode is just that—a great mode to learn the nuances of Rhythm games without the game over screens.

[b]Variety For Days[/b] – You know that old saying, 'Variety is the spice of Life'? The Metronomicon has it in spades. 

With the music, unless you've got a thing against modern music like rock and dubstep, you'll most definitely find a handful (or a lot of) songs that you will replay the stages of constantly or chill out with in the DJ Room.

With the combat, you can mix and match to your heart's content with a very deep system. Do you run with a full damage build of a Berserker, a Thief, a Warrior, and an Exploder, believing that the best defense is kersplodinating everything before it has a chance to even attack? Do you play the Protector more as a tank, soaking up damage for the rest of the party, or as combat support, stunning enemies, dealing damage right back, and even healing the party? Do you want to take advantage of your streak building skills and use an item that automatically buffs your party as you hit the upper double digits, or do you use an item that gives your characters a substantial raw boost in power standard?

And if you find vanilla combat too easy or too boring, there's also a large number of ways to vary up your experience. Too easy? Rack up the difficulty. Looking for something different? Try the arena challenges, where you fight with preset teams, and have modifiers like constantly falling rocks to dodge, spinning and wobbling notes, or trying to “befriend” monsters for an entire song, healing and defending yourself as they try to rip your face off.

[b]Awesome Music, Awesome Track Choreography[/b] – Worried that the notes won't match up, rendering the music background noise to a game of memory? Fear not: from my experience, all three difficulties and all four tracks at any given time sync up to the music, and you can even adjust the latency of your inputs for devices and monitors with delays.

[b]Silliness[/b] – A fantasy world is being terrorized by mysterious night clubs falling from the sky, attracting monsters who destroy everything around it by morning. A school is established, teaching humans how to dance and fight at the same time, in an effort to produce graduates who will infiltrate these parties, shut them down, and ultimately destroy the source.

The Metronimicon is very, very, VERY aware that this is a very silly plot, to say the least, and it runs with it.

Your black mage Violet is called the “Exploder” and true to form, she's positively giddy at the prospect of “kersplodinating” legions of bad guys, and any day where the world is due to be destroyed and she needs to blow up the biggest baddie in the world is a great day indeed. Enemies include haunted disco balls that produce weapons and tools out of neon lights, feisty hermit crabs wearing sweet bling, mermaids with rayguns, giant bears in wife beaters, the aforementioned giant tentacle monster with neon glow-in-the-dark face paint, and even creepy tiny lizards who need to stand up on a box to actually reach you. The descriptions for your sidequests involve saving the arena's hotdog stand from ravenous monsters, wearing experimental shades from the laboratory that make you completely colour-blind, and going through three strong straight while the arena mistress goes off for lunch.

And this isn't even getting into the equipment, like the “Dirt Endirtener” which is useful for killing lightning elementals and building sick sandcastles, the “Full-Body lipgloss” that'll make you shine like the sun, and the “Bottom Flappy Bit,” the most important part of any piece of armour that you should open before using.

In an industry filled to the brim with games trying to be taken “seriously” with “mature” plots and themes, The Metronomicon bucks that trend with a swift kick that's part of a sick series of dance moves, all to the tune of awesome music.

[h1]The Bad[/h1]

[b]The Buff and Debuff UI[/b] – Both are given as tiny icons on the bottom of the screen, with only two colours: opaque “active” and a blinking” about to “wear off” mode. Neither are very helpful in terms of information, how long it will last, and oftentimes, you'll have to develop an instinct to know how long a certain buff lasts before you need to cast it again—and oftentimes, in the heat of a complex series of notes, you really can't check and only notice until it's long run out.

[b]Silliness[/b] – Obviously, such a lighthearted, not-serious, and colourful game will have people that find the humour and the comedic elements lacking, annoying, and falling flat.

[h1]Should I get this?[/h1]

Absolutely. Rhythm game fans, RPG fanatics looking for something different, even just people willing to jump into a new genre if it means getting away from the “Gritty, Realistic, Modern” games and their “serious” plots for “serious, mature” trend the AAA industry is so keen in going down.

Buy it, play it, tell your friends about it—The Metronomicon is a real gem that is more than worth your time and money.

* Favourites include “Live It Up” by Shiny Toy Guns, “I Thought The Future Would Be Cooler” by YACHT, “For The Love Of God” by Rosie, and of course, the game's theme song: “Fighting with the Melody” by Jimmy Urine of Mindless Self Indulgence.

25827115.review:
[b]Absolutely outstanding game that blends the RPG and rhythm genres near perfectly.[/b]

The trailer didn't sell me on this particularly well, either. I watched a friend play for a bit and decided to take the plunge. And I'm really glad I did. [i]The Metronomicon[/i] is highly polished, overflowing with content, and most importantly - really [i]really[/i] fun. [b]I find it hard to turn it off, honestly.[/b]

[i]Essentially, when you complete sequences of dance moves by matching the arrows, you perform some action like attack or heal, etc.[/i] You can choose what action you perform by how long you keep the sequence going. There is a lot going on, and I mean that in a good way. Pitting elementals against each other is how you exploit weakness (ie. fire kills lush earth, and water kills fire, and so on). You get equipable and functional loot. You build your party and swap different classes in and out. There are different modes and they are all really well done.

The music is high energy and quite varied. There is a lot of it, in my opinion. I hear there will be more coming as DLC, which is awesome. [b]It is also my opinion that the worst part of this game is debatebly the artwork.[/b] It is not [i]horrible[/i] per se, but I just wish it were different. At least the animations are funny with how their hips gyrate lol. The enemies have a lot of 'character' lol.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Really great blend of two genres that makes for some very addictive gameplay. I have a hard time putting it down.
+Controller support is good.
+Tons of content. I could see getting dozens of hours out of this.

25810788.review:
Link to full review:
http://mammothgamers.com/2016/09/metronomicon-review/

Review summary:

"The first thing you are greeted with when booting up The Metronomicon for the first time is a small medieval town soaked in neon, complete with flashing lights and electronica music. The next thing is a bit of exposition, followed by a brief combat scenario that acts as a tutorial for the Guitar Hero and Dance Dance Revolution inspired RPG."

"The story of The Metronomicon follows four students of a dancing combat school (of sorts) where they are trained to fight the monsters that have been invading their realm with the power of dance. The invading monsters have brought with them unruly music, throwing raves all across the realm, disturbing the peace, and unsettling the locals. It’s up to the player and their band of plucky adventurers to dance these monsters to death while meeting friends and gathering loot along the way. I may be paraphrasing a bit, but the story itself, while cheesy in a lighthearted and somewhat charming and funny way, is entirely forgettable. But that’s okay, because the meat of the game, the note hitting EDM infused RPG combat, stands on its own without any need for exposition."

"If you’ve ever played Guitar Hero or Dance Dance Revolution, you already have a pretty good idea of how this game plays. Players will enter battle with a party of four heroes, each with their own unique set of skills and equipment. As monsters are defeated and songs are cleared, the heroes will level up, increasing their base stats, the strength of their skills, and learning some new skills along the way. While in combat, only one hero can act at a time, adding a layer of strategy and forethought to the game. Players will toggle between heroes, hit the notes in the track as they fall to the bottom (as in the aforementioned inspirations), and perform an attack, buff, or heal based on what skills the hero currently has equipped. Skills can be equipped in three slots – low, middle, and high. The higher the slot, the stronger the skill’s effect will be. Using different skills is based on how long the string of notes hit is on the selected hero. It only takes a few notes to hit each tier, but hitting higher tiers can be tricky, as any mistake will break your chain thereby defaulting your move to the last tier you successfully hit. There is a risk/reward aspect to character builds, as placing vital skills in higher tiers can both help immensely when activated, or cause you to effectively lose a turn  if missed or interrupted."

"There are a variety of game modes available to keep players coming back for more, grinding out levels, earning gear, and obtaining Street Cred (the game’s currency) to build new facilities and unlock gameplay features. Free play allows players to casually play any unlocked songs, while the Arena offers sets of challenges to push player’s skills in an effort to earn more loot to strengthen your heroes. There are side quests to complete and three difficulties for those looking for an even greater challenge. Those looking for a reason to dust off their USB guitars and DDR mats can also do so here as the game supports both input methods. But for all the content on offer, don’t come to this game expecting a deep and engrossing experience. Though it never deliberately bills itself as such, it’s easy to focus on and get lost in the RPG aspects of the game and find the experience to be lacking. This is a game intended for short play sessions, not lengthy binges. It is a rhythm game at its core, with a role playing layer on top, not vice versa. For as much variety and replayability as the RPG mechanics can add, they are relatively shallow and those looking for an RPG may leave disappointed. The songs may not appeal to everyone either, and while there is definitely some variety, expect a heavy dose of techno, house, electronica, and dubstep in most worlds."

TL;DR: Overall, it is an easily recommendable game. Simple, but enjoyable. If you are craving a good rhythm game, give it a shot!

25766625.review:
**FULL DISCLOSURE**
I was given my copy of the game for free and have been helping playtest The Metronomicon for several months. That being said, I will be giving my full and honest opinion of the game.

==The Concept==
The Metronomicon is the fusion of rhythm style Rock Band and Guitar Hero style lane gameplay with a fully fleshed out RPG with unique and voiced characters, skills, equipment, and detailed storyline.

==Gameplay==
The Metronomicon immediately throws you a curveball going with four lanes of notes instead of just one. Each lane corresponds to one of your four party members. To cast various abilities set by the player, notes must be played on rhythm with the music in order to charge up and cast their abilities. Think of Chrono Trigger style active combat except instead of just waiting for a bar to fill up, you play musical notes to charge up your abilities.

Each song plays out with monsters coming at you. Defeating them earns you currency you can use to unlock songs as well as a chance at equipment drops. Each stage also comes with a mini-boss that can be defeated for a special type of currency to further enhance your party members.

As you defeat enemies and stages your party members will level up (just like an RPG!) giving them access to new skills and making them stronger. As you continue your adventure through the various lands, you’ll be gearing up, refining your character loadouts, and farming up loot drops just like an RPG but to some dope ass music! Normally I’m not a particular fan of the straight up Rock Band/Guitar Hero gameplay, but the RPG framework tying everything together struck the perfect chord with me. (GET IT?! That’s a music joke!)

==Music==
With the included original songs composed for the game, the Metronomicon offers 50 tracks, some with and some without lyrics. The soundtrack is amazing. Every song was hand choreographed and feels great to play on all the difficulty settings. I personally play on Easy and Medium difficulty, with Hard being a little out of my league. For those rhythm game fanatics out there, I think Hard will definitely prove a decent challenge.

==Controls==
The game can be played with a controller, mouse and keyboard, and even a dance pad, or quite frankly, just about any device that can be bound to keys! I play with a mouse and keyboard and have had no issues. The controls can be completely customized, so find a setup that works and is comfortable for you.

==Conclusion==
As I stated above, I received the game for free and have been playtesting it. Take everything here with a grain of salt of course. This review has probably sounded like a big ad for the game, but honestly, any negatives I found I had with it while playtesting were changed or addressed during development. I love this game. I wouldn’t have already put 30+ hours into it already if I didn’t love it. I know I’ll be playing it all over again now that the game is being released.

I can definitely recommend this title to anyone who enjoys this genre of gaming.

25766597.review:
[b] Target Audience: [/b] [I] Rhythm Fans or Those wanting to test out a Rhythm experience [/i]

[b] Summary: [/b]  
Rhythm players really need to give this a hard look, because the game not only combines two genres rather well, it feels rather fresh in the Rhythm genre in particular. It's the game design and how it uniquely emphasizes the strategy element that really shines here: every decisions that the developers made seems to have been well thought out. The chaos of trying not only to juggle the 4 different characters and their spells, but doing that while keeping yourself alive and noticing elemental weaknesses and the such, it all really works. While it's more leinant in the rhythm genre then others, it works due to the RPG elements. And the soundtrack for the most part gives a good variety of songs that are of a reasonable quality, despite there being a few duds in there. Granted, there is a rock/pop focus, but every now and again you'll get a surprise of a 8 bit tune. In the end, The Metronomicon not only feels a lot different from a lot of the rhythm games on the market, it ends up being addictive and something that you won't want to put down. A definite day one purchase for rhythm gamers out there, and a great gateway game to the genre for those who have always wondered if they'd enjoy it. 

[b]Video Review: [/b] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f44R5PEkOGo

[u] Lists: [/u]
[b]Positives:[/b]
[list]
[*] This may seem like a weird ass comparison, but the dual gameplay with the rhythm and the strategy element reminds me a lot of the World Ends With You. You need to focus on the rhythm, while the back of your mind is focusing on what spells you need to cast. It REALLY works.
[*] The spell element and knowing when to move on and when to keep going in terms of the levels to cast works well here in the strategy element. Taking into account enemy's elements, and what your party needs, you'll have to stay on top of things.
[*] The game design as a whole. For example, while the game is more leinant then most rhythm games in terms of timing: it's done due to the strategy element that's played out here. It's purposeful, it makes sense given the implementation, and feels like they really thought about how all these pieces fit together. That's the sign of a well designed game.
[*] Good variety in the characters to allow for a wide variety of strategies. Defensive, offensive, buff wise, etc. 
[*] Good Difficulty curve. No grinding needed, but enough challenge so that you consider getting a level or two. The hard difficulty is a good challenge. 
[*] The ability to switch characters and how it affects gameplay is implemented well. Timely switches when you're in trouble or when you need to cast a spell right now puts the strategy at the forefront.
[*] Like how the status effects actually effects your ability to stay on rhythm. 
[*] For the most part, a very, very good soundtrack. There's some highlights here that really stand out, and there's a good variety despite there being a pop/rock focus.
[/list]

[b]Negatives:[/b]
[list]
[*] The UI could be designed a little better, as the focus on the middle of the screen needed to be taken advantage of. Some elements on the edge are hard to see when you're trying to focus on hitting notes.
[*] The story really takes a back seat to the gameplay. It's not bad, it just feels like more can be done with it.
[*] Wanted to see more done with the attack animations in terms of the dance theme. Some times it works, but other times it really, really doesn't. 
[*] There's a few bad duds in the album here. Like bad bad ones.
[/list]

[h1]Спасти мир от музыкальных монстров[/h1]
Несмотря на все каноны жанра, Метрономикон имеет недурной сюжет. Всё крутится вокруг одной из школ, борющейся против засилья бесконечных вечеринок со стороны инопланетян, да и вообще монстряков разных. Их цели пока не понятны землянам, но многие люди обучаются мастерству музыки ради благой цели  - победить захватчиков и восстановить в мире такое хрупкое танцевальное равновесие. Нестандартненько, ничего не скажешь. Всё это ещё приправлено и отличными видеовставками, в которых постепенно рассказывается вся предыстория описываемых событий. Но стоит сказать о небольшом не раскрытии персонажей, хотя это и не является обязательным, ведь больше мы будем учавствовать, нежели наблюдать за перипетиями отношений. 
[h1]"Оглянись вокруг, сынок..."[/h1]
Геймплей отдалённо походит на Rock Band или Guitar Hero. В нашем распоряжении находятся четыре героя, каждый со своими уникальными способностями и умениями. Их треки представлены знакомыми многими "гитарными" грифами, по которым и движутся нотки. Переключаясь между ними, мы и будем добиваться успеха. Просто? Ещё бы. На первый взгляд. В игре имеется три уровня сложности, в которых постепенно нот становятся больше, а уровень врагов повышается с катастрофической быстротой. 
Кроме того, интересной фишкой являются и стихии. Их тут пять: огонь, вода, земля, молния и физическая грубая силушка. Каждый противник, в свою очередь, имеет ту или иную специализацию. Бить огненного огнём - непозволительная и глупая роскошь. Чтобы добиться чёткого и быстрого "отлетания" врагов, необходимо запомнить, какая стихия является наиболее слабой или сильной к другой. Напоминает игровой процесс Magicka, но ощущается совсем по-другому.
Метрономикон ещё и RPG. Достигается это за счёт большого количества умений, лута и уровней. Первые представлены широко для всех героев (они, кстати, открываются при прохождении), являясь их пассивными и активными умениями. Герой во время битвы может иметь 3 активных умения, активизируя их просто удачными попаданиями. Второй (лут) выпадает в шести случаях из десяти, показывая, что особых заморочек с поиском нужной вещи нет. Иногда попадаются очень необходимые предметы, а иногда натуральный хлам, но он уместно разбавляется прекрасным юморным описанием. С юмором у игры, к слову, всё очень неплохо. Смешные фразочки можно услышать на протяжении всех видеовставок. И третьи (уровни) нужны лишь для того, чтобы показать развитие героя. Идя по лестнице повышения опыта, игрок видит, как улучшаются и открываются новые заклинания персонажей. Все эти составляющие вместе гармонично создают такой геймплей, от которого не вытащишь даже вкусным ужином или скидками в стиме.  

Но неужели это всё будет происходить только в сюжетном режиме? Ничего подобного, ибо Метрономикон очень богатый на такие аспекты продукт. Кроме приключения, игрок имеет свободный режим (простой выбор любого героя и исполнение песенки в своё удовольствие), выживание (тяжелая артиллерия для парней поопытнее и мужественнее), арену (особые задания, имеющие описание и больше направленные на получение вещей и "уважухи" - особого ресурса для открывания различных второстепенных менюшных плюшек) и локальный кооператив, увы, не мультиплеерный. Маловато будет?
[h1]Сделайте погромче, пожалуйста![/h1]
Музыка. Я просто перечислю более известных и лучших представителей, встречаемых в игре, а вы уже сами для себя всё решите - GosT, Dan Terminus, Perturbator с его замечательной "She Is Young, She Is Beautiful, She Is Next", J-Punch, 	
Shiny Toy Guns, Zenbi "Down" и ещё многие другие, идеально вписываемые во весь геймплей. Кроме электроники, иногда встречаются и рок-металл композиции, правда, немного лично мне не зашедших, но их наличие говорит о не однобокости музыкального сопровождения. Приятна и озвучка персонажей, особенно их выкрики во время битвы.
[h1]Танцующие котики, аккуратно![/h1]
Графика же немного нарисована, выглядит стильно и красивенько. Герои имеют свои особенные мелкие детали, а одинаковые противники различаются даже в аксессуарах, если имеют разные стихии. Фоны выполнены на том же уровне, радует и смена локаций не только между мирами, но и в самом "паке". 
[h1]Да это была лучшая вечеринка в истории![/h1]
The Metronomicon: Slay The Dance Floor предоставляет настоящим фанатам ритм-игр великолепную возможность уйти в музыкальный запой и не возвращаться оттуда часов так 20 точно. Разнообразие режимов, интересный и необычный игровой процесс, просто космическая (надеюсь, мою отсылку поняли) музыка и приятная графика сопровождает игрока на всём протяжении, не давая ему возможности уйти. И это не потому, что она заставляет; ты сам не хочешь заканчивать это удивительное и неповторимое приключение.
8,5 найденных любимых исполнителей из 10

40590684.review:
[h1]Welcome to your place[/h1]

  [b]Метрономикон[/b] - представитель "ритм-игры" с элементами РПГ. Окунитесь в незамысловатую историю о музыке, героях и злодеях. По сюжету, мы управляем выпускнимами школы "ритмичных боевых искусств", что сражаются против полчищ монстров. Последние устраивают отпадно-разрушительные тусовки во имя танцев! Нам предстоит узнать, что это за энергия танцев, что наполняет данный мир. Откуда она взялась, и кто ей балуется (Мы как хорошие парни, используем эту энергию лишь во благо).

 Итак, нам предстоит отплясывать под крутые биты, созданные популярными музыкальными исполнителями в узких кругах. Чего стоит лишь упоминания о [i]Jimmy Urine, Shiny Toy Guns, Perturbator (Hotline Miami 2), Viking Guitar, Mega Run и DJ SULTAN[/i]. 

В итоге у нас есть 4 героя в команде. Кадому из которых соответствует музыкальная дорожка с нотами (Схоже с Guitar Hero). С помощью цепочки из правильных попаданий по нотам - герой кастует скилы. У скилов есть стихии, к которым они относятся (Огонь->Земля->Вода->Молния), как и у врагов. Поэтому определённые стихии (скилы), лучше против определённого типа врагов.

Меня игра определённо/нереально зацепила своей оригинальностью и треками (не все треки хороши, но это не делает игру хуже). Даже после прохождения сюжетной истории, нам есть чем заняться. Пробиваться в рейтинге среди лучших исполнителей треков, челленджи, бесконечный режим.

10 битов из 10 _)

[b]P.S.[/b] Отдельное спасибо [b]Sigmar's Sausage[/b] за подарок в виде данной игры.
[b]P.S.S.[/b] Игру прошёл на лёгком уровне. Считаю что без геймпада в сложный режим соваться нет смысла)

39718158.review:
I was once that guy who had to have all the rhythm games to convince myself that I actually had rhythm. Well the days of the plastic instruments and dance pads are in my review mirror, but here comes this game, The Metronomicon, that just gives me a nostalgic rush. The thing is that this game has a bit of a twist. Now I know that the next statement, the mention of the genre, will have some of you scratching your heads, but I swear the developer actually made this work almost to complete perfection. This game is a RPG/Rhythm game. I used the slash because this game is equal in both parts. There's a heavy emphasis on getting the rhythm parts down pat, but there's also a lot of love and attention given to the RPG aspects of the game.

You will battle through song stages and as you take on the game you will unlock new characters, have the chance to gain new items that will power up your characters. You will of course be leveling up your characters as you go through the game, and there are going to be special challenges for those who are looking to truly show off their skills. 

Graphically, I love the lay out that the game has. You'll be controlling up to 4 characters at a time, each will have 3 levels of skills that can be unleashed depending on how long you can hold the rhythm in their section. Once their skill has been deployed there will be a cool down time and you'll have to take on other characters sections. The thing is that you're going to have to find that beat and rhythm that allows you to take down the enemies, or the challenge you have in front of you. If you miss too many notes you're going to die, if you're being sloppy there's a chance that the song will end and you will not have completed the objective for the level.

This game definitely isn't for everyone, and there is some tweaking that you'll have to do to get the beats to line up with when visually the keys are supposed to hit, but once you have that set, you are in for a challenging good fun. 

There's also the fact that there's a levels of difficulty, so if you are one of those gamers who think that EASY is something that you can't even acknowledge, know this, there's medium and hard that I'm sure will have some of you having nightmares, depending on the songs. Then again maybe that's just me trying to take on some of my favorite more challenging songs with a ramped up difficulty.

This game deserves a spot on your gaming list, and I HIGHLY recommend that you play with a gamepad, however I have heard that you might actually be able to play with other gaming devices, but I have yet to try it. This game gets that Altered Confusion stamp of approval.
